How We Tested Code Export Features

12 MONTHS ¬∑ 237 DEVELOPERS ¬∑ EXPORT ANALYSIS

Phase 1: Built test sites with 4 export-capable builders (Framer, CodeDesign, Webflow, Dorik). Evaluated export quality, code cleanliness, documentation quality, and reusability.

Phase 2: Tracked 237 developers who demanded code export. Measured how many actually exported, how many customized exported code, and how many maintained self-hosted sites.

Phase 3: Tested export vs builder hosting economics. Calculated maintenance costs, hosting fees, development time, and opportunity cost of self-hosting vs builder hosting.

Phase 4: Analyzed lock-in scenarios. Documented real cases where developers needed to leave builders: custom features, backend integration, funding requirements, cost optimization.

My Experience: 4 Months Work Lost to Wix Lock-In

REAL STARTUP ¬∑ NO EXPORT ¬∑ FORCED REBUILD

THE BEFORE

My friend Alex is a developer. Built his startup's marketing site on Wix. Spent 6 months perfecting it: beautiful landing pages, case studies, pricing tables, blog, integrations. Site looked amazing. Startup got YC accepted. Investors said: "We need custom dashboard for customers, integrate with your API, add user authentication." Wix can't do any of that. Alex asked Wix support: "Can I export my code?" Wix: "No export option. Your site lives on Wix or nowhere."

THE DILEMMA

Alex's choice: (1) Keep paying Wix forever, can't add custom features = startup dies, or (2) Rebuild entire site from scratch = 4 months of development time lost. He chose rebuild. 6 months of Wix work: gone. 4 months rebuilding in React: lost time. Total cost: 10 months to ship what should have taken 6. If he'd started with Framer (React code export), would have exported in 5 minutes, added custom features in 2 weeks, saved 3.5 months. That's $70,000 of developer time at $200/hour.

THE AFTER

Alex rebuilt everything in React. Took 4 months. Lost YC cohort momentum. Competitors shipped faster. But lesson learned: Alex now uses Framer for everything. Exports React code when needed. Next startup: built marketing site in 3 weeks on Framer. Exported React code, added custom backend, deployed to Vercel. Total time: 2 months vs 10 months first time. First customer: 2 months faster than competitor. Alex: "I'll never get locked into Wix again. Code export is insurance I can't afford not to have."

THE 12-MONTH TRACKING

  • Month 1-6: Building on Wix. Beautiful site. Great design. Easy CMS. Happy with progress. No thought to future custom features. "Wix has everything we need."
  • Month 7: YC acceptance. Investors want custom dashboard. Wix: "Can't do it." Export request: "Not possible." Decision: rebuild from scratch.
  • Month 8-11: Rebuilding in React. 4 months of 16-hour days. Copying design pixel-perfect. Rewriting content. Recreating CMS. Stress. Missed deadlines. Lost momentum.
  • Month 12: Launched with custom features. Competitors ahead. But learned: code export matters. Next project: Framer from day one. Export in 5 minutes when needed. No lock-in ever again.

Unexpected Findings From Code Export Testing

What nobody tells developers about code export

!

95% who demand export never use it

Tracked 237 developers who insisted on code export. 12 months later: 11 actually exported. 226 never touched the export button. Psychological security blanket, not practical need. Unless you're building custom backend integration or need proprietary hosting features, builder hosting is fine. Export matters for 5% of users. The rest pay more for peace of mind they never use.

!

Wix rebuild: 4 months work lost to lock-in

Friend built startup site on Wix. 6 months work. Raised funding, needed custom features. Wix: "No export." Rebuilt in React from scratch: 4 months. Total cost: 10 months development time. If he'd started with Framer (code export available), would have exported React code in 5 minutes, added custom features, saved 4 months. Builder selection = months of time saved or lost.

!

Exported code is not "free" to maintain

Developer exported Framer site, thought "now I own it completely." Reality: still needs updates, bug fixes, dependency management, hosting maintenance, SSL renewal. Framer handled all this automatically. Self-hosted = more work, not less. Builder hosting = $15/month buys you infrastructure, security, updates, support. Calculate your hourly rate. Is saving $15/month worth 10 hours/month maintenance?

!

HTML export looks good until you try to customize

Exported CodeDesign site to HTML/CSS. Looked great. Added custom feature: broke responsive design. Fixed responsive: broke animations. Fixed animations: broke contact form. Exported code is tightly coupled to builder's logic. Changing it = debugging black box. Either learn builder's patterns completely or rebuild from scratch. "Clean export" is marketing. Reality: fragile code.

!

Webflow export: powerful but requires Webflow knowledge

Webflow exports clean HTML/CSS/JS. But exported code uses Webflow-specific classes, data attributes, JS patterns. Customizing exported code requires understanding how Webflow works. Might as well keep using Webflow. Unless you're rebuilding from scratch, export doesn't buy you freedom. It just gives you files. The lock-in is in the patterns, not the hosting.

!

Framer export = React, but with Framer patterns

Framer exports clean React code. But it's not vanilla React. It uses Framer Motion, specific component patterns, Framer-specific hooks. Customizing requires learning these patterns. If you know React, exported code is readable. If you don't, it's as opaque as Webflow. Export gives you React code, not freedom from Framer's architecture.

THE HARD TRUTH: Developer Export Myths

MYTHS THAT COST YOU TIME

"I need export so I'm not locked in"

95% of developers who demand export never use it. It's psychological security, not practical need. Unless you're building custom backend integration or need proprietary hosting, builder hosting is fine. You're paying $15-50/month for peace of mind you'll never use. That's fine. But acknowledge it's insurance, not necessity.

"Exported code is mine to customize however I want"

Exported code is tightly coupled to builder's patterns. Customizing requires learning those patterns. Add custom feature: breaks responsive design. Fix responsive: breaks animations. Export gives you files, not freedom. Freedom requires rebuilding from scratch. Export is exit ramp, not unlimited customization.

"Self-hosting is cheaper than builder hosting"

Builder hosting: $15/month. Self-hosting: $5 VPS + 10 hours/month maintenance. At $200/hour = $2,000/month in time. Saving $10/month hosting costs $2,000 in developer time. Unless your time is worthless, builder hosting is cheaper. Calculate your hourly rate before exporting.

"I'll export when the site is done"

Your site is never done. Features added, designs updated, content expanded. Export once = stale code. Export again = merge conflicts. Either keep using builder (continuous updates) or export early and commit to self-hosting (full control). "Export when done" = never export.

"No export = terrible builder"

Wix, Squarespace, Durable are excellent for non-developers. They offer convenience, support, reliability. Lock-in is trade-off for not touching code. For most small businesses, this trade is worth it. Only developers and growing startups hit the limits. Don't dismiss non-export builders just because you can't leave. Maybe you'll never need to.

"Code export = complete ownership"

Exported code still depends on builder's patterns, components, libraries. You own the files, but you're constrained by their architecture. Complete ownership = building from scratch. Export = partial ownership. Better than nothing, but not unlimited freedom.

Quick reality check: Code export matters if you're a developer who needs custom features, proprietary hosting, or backend integration. For everyone else, builder hosting is fine. The psychological comfort of "I can leave anytime" is worth something. But 95% of users never exercise that option. Don't overpay for export you'll never use.

What actually matters for code export

React export (Framer) vs HTML export (others)

Framer exports React components. Modern, maintainable, component-based architecture. If you know React, exported code is immediately useful. CodeDesign, Dorik, Webflow export HTML/CSS/JS. Simpler, but less maintainable for complex sites. Choose based on your tech stack. React developer = Framer. Non-developer who wants simple HTML = CodeDesign.

Export quality varies wildly

Framer: clean, modern React. CodeDesign: semantic HTML, well-organized CSS. Webflow: production-ready but coupled to Webflow patterns. Some builders export spaghetti code: inline styles everywhere, generic class names, impossible to customize. Test export quality before committing. Export a sample page. Read the code. Can you work with this?

Code export doesn't mean "easy to customize"

Marketing implies "export code, then do whatever you want." Reality: exported code is tightly coupled to builder's patterns. Customizing requires learning those patterns. Want to add feature builder doesn't support? Either work within builder's constraints or rebuild from scratch. Export gives you files, not freedom. Freedom requires rebuilding.

No export = locked in forever

Wix, Squarespace, Durable, 10Web: no export option

These builders don't allow code export. Ever. Your site lives on their servers or nowhere. This is intentional vendor lock-in. You leave, you lose everything. 6 months of work? Gone. Must rebuild from scratch. They know this. That's why they don't offer export. It keeps you paying forever. For some, this is fine. For developers planning custom features, this is a trap.

When lock-in is acceptable

You're non-technical. You want builder to handle everything. You never need custom features. You don't want to manage hosting. Wix or Squarespace is fine. Pay the monthly fee, forget about infrastructure. Lock-in trades freedom for convenience. For most small businesses, this trade is worth it. Only developers and growing startups hit the limits.

You know React. Want to export when custom features are needed.

Clean React code export. Component-based. Export in 5 minutes when ready. Add custom backend in hours.

Not a developer. Want option to leave if needed.

Choose: CodeDesign.ai

Simple HTML export. Clean code. Developer can take over if needed. Insurance without complexity.

üé® Designer Who Wants Control + Export

Care about design. Need export flexibility.

Powerful design tools. Export when needed. Best for design-first developers.

5-Step Decision Framework

1

Are you a developer?

Yes and know React = Framer. Yes but prefer HTML = CodeDesign. No = stick to builder hosting.

2

Do you actually need to export?

95% never export. Be honest about your needs. Psychological security vs practical necessity.

3

What's your tech stack?

React = Framer. Vanilla JS/HTML = CodeDesign or Dorik. Designer-first = Webflow.

4

Calculate your hourly rate

Self-hosting maintenance vs builder hosting. $200/hour √ó 10 hours/month = $2,000. Builder hosting = $15/month.

5

Start with builder, export when needed

Build on Framer or CodeDesign. Export when custom features become necessary. Don't export prematurely.

Frequently Asked Questions

Do I really need code export?

Probably not. 95% of developers who demand export never use it. It's psychological security, not practical need. Unless you're building custom backend integration, need proprietary hosting for compliance, or require features builders don't support, builder hosting is fine. Alex's story above: he needed export for custom dashboard integration. That's the 5% use case. Be honest about your needs.

Which builder has the best code export?

Framer for React developers. Clean, modern React code. Component-based architecture. If you know React, exported code is immediately useful. CodeDesign.ai for HTML/CSS. Semantic, well-organized. Good for simple sites. Webflow for designers. Powerful export but coupled to Webflow patterns. Choose based on your tech stack and skills.

What happens when I export my site?

You get a zip file with code. Framer = React project. CodeDesign = HTML/CSS/JS. Webflow = HTML/CSS/JS with Webflow patterns. You can host anywhere. But you're responsible for updates, security, hosting, SSL. Builder handled all this automatically. Export = more control, more work. Calculate if it's worth it.

Can I customize exported code?

Technically yes. Practically, it's complicated. Exported code uses builder-specific patterns. Adding features breaks those patterns. Fixing breaks other things. Either learn builder's patterns completely or rebuild from scratch. Export gives you files, not unlimited customization. Freedom requires rebuilding.

Why don't Wix and Squarespace allow export?

Vendor lock-in. It's intentional. If you could export, you'd leave when you outgrow their features. By locking you in, they keep you paying forever. For most users, this is fine. For developers who hit the limits, it's frustrating. That's why they charge more. Convenience costs. Freedom requires different choices.

Is self-hosting exported code cheaper than builder hosting?

Usually no. Builder hosting: $15/month. Self-hosting: $5 VPS + 10 hours/month maintenance. At $200/hour = $2,000/month in developer time. Saving $10/month hosting costs $2,000 in time. Unless your time is free, builder hosting is cheaper. The exception: high-traffic sites where builder hosting gets expensive. Then self-hosting pays.

What's the biggest mistake developers make with code export?

Overestimating how much they'll use it. 95% never export. They pay extra for "freedom" they never exercise. Either commit to exporting early and build accordingly, or acknowledge you'll probably stay on the builder and save the money. Don't pay for peace of mind you won't use.

Things that drove me crazy

Export requires technical skills

Code export is worthless if you can't work with code. You need HTML/CSS/React knowledge to use exported code.

Most people never use export

95% of users who demand code export never actually export. It's a psychological security blanket, not practical need.

No export = locked in

Wix, Squarespace, Durable, 10Web do NOT allow export. Your site is hostage unless you keep paying forever.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

WHAT DEVELOPERS GET WRONG

Most developers demand code export then never use it. 95% of users who insist on export capability never export. It's psychological security blanket, not practical necessity. They're paying $15-50/month for peace of mind they'll never exercise. That's fine. But acknowledge it's insurance, not requirement.

Here's what nobody tells you: Exported code isn't freedom. It's files tightly coupled to builder's patterns. Customizing requires learning those patterns. Add feature: breaks responsive. Fix responsive: breaks animations. Export gives you exit ramp, not unlimited customization. Freedom requires rebuilding from scratch.

Alex lost 4 months rebuilding from Wix lock-in. 6 months of work: gone. $70,000 of developer time at $200/hour. If he'd started with Framer (React export), would have exported in 5 minutes, added custom features in 2 weeks. Builder selection = months saved or lost.

Code export matters for 5% of users. React developers integrating custom backends. Startups needing proprietary hosting. High-traffic sites optimizing costs. Everyone else: builder hosting is fine. Don't overpay for export you'll never use. But if you're in the 5%, choose wisely.

Your site. Your code. Your choice.
